If you did the calendar shiz that I posted, it checks if it’s saturday or sunday and does it for you.
[/quote]
I can’t find where the xp shiz is… >.>[/quote]

Look at any add experience method in your skill files (woodcutting, ect)

It tells you exactly what file it is in.

item.title: Will give REP++ if you know how to add double xp weekend! [OPEN]
item.dc:creator: @totalystylin1 totalystylin1
item.description:
@totalystylin1 wrote:

[quote=“Pure Slay, post:26, topic:414272”][quote author=totalystylin1 link=topic=516236.msg3746229#msg3746229 date=1315722049]
still didnt work.
[/quote]

No, the code works. Your brain can’t just function enough to search for what EVERYONE has been telling you. Want Emily to hold your hand?

  • Open your source folder
  • Grab that thing next to your computer, it’s called a mouse
  • Now left click on the folder until you find your Skills file
  • Right click and edit that file
  • Now don’t freak out, it’ll be fine.
  • Search for “addXp”
  • Add the code I provided in your source
  • Add these imports at the top
import java.sql.Date;
import java.text.SimpleDateFormat;
import java.util.Calendar;
  • Click file & save
  • YOU MADE IT
  • Lets go of your hand.[/quote]
    Ok. i think tht worked. How ofted does it do it? O.o Or, will i have to keep changeing it my self every weekend?

Read full topic

item.title: Will give REP++ if you know how to add double xp weekend! [OPEN]
item.dc:creator: @F_A_I_L_S Fails
item.description:
@F_A_I_L_S wrote:

[quote=“Pure Slay, post:20, topic:414272”]Way to over think something very simple:

Find your addXp method, find something like this:

player.getSkills().xp[skill] += exp;

Either:
A) Do it by hand every weekend:

player.getSkills().xp[skill] += exp * 2;

Or B:

Calendar currentDate = Calendar.getInstance();
		SimpleDateFormat formatter=  new SimpleDateFormat("yyyy/MMM/dd HH:mm:ss");
		String day = formatter.format(currentDate.getTime());
		int oldLevel = player.getSkills().getLevelForXp(skill);
		if(Date.valueOf(day).getDay() == 6 || Date.valueOf(day).getDay() == 0) {
			player.getSkills().xp[skill] += exp * 2;
		} else {
			player.getSkills().xp[skill] += exp;
		}

Auto checks if it’s the weekend.[/quote]Amazing job, I however am not good with PI’s or “525’s” This better work, so this thread can just be over already.

Read full topic
item.source: Will give REP++ if you know how to add double xp weekend! [OPEN]

item.title: Will give REP++ if you know how to add double xp weekend! [OPEN]
item.dc:creator: @Pure_Slay Pure Slay
item.description:
@Pure_Slay wrote:

Way to over think something very simple:

Find your addXp method, find something like this:

player.getSkills().xp[skill] += exp;

Either:
A) Do it by hand every weekend:

player.getSkills().xp[skill] += exp * 2;

Or B:

Calendar currentDate = Calendar.getInstance();
		SimpleDateFormat formatter=  new SimpleDateFormat("yyyy/MMM/dd HH:mm:ss");
		String day = formatter.format(currentDate.getTime().getDay());
		int oldLevel = player.getSkills().getLevelForXp(skill);
		if(Date.valueOf(day).getDay() == 6 || Date.valueOf(day).getDay() == 0) {
			player.getSkills().xp[skill] += exp * 2;
		} else {
			player.getSkills().xp[skill] += exp;
		}

Auto checks if it’s the weekend.

Read full topic

item.description:
@F_A_I_L_S wrote:

I don’t care who spoonfeeds, I just don’t. I think people will never learn if they don’t teach themselves. That’s all, you can spoonfeed all you want, but you will never see me doing it. I’m 100% against it. It’s not difficult to research your problems, and learn off other codes. I will however point them in the right direction.

omfg… its not a fucking 525 its PI.
[/quote]Agreed, it’s a PI, If you all didn’t know, PI is 317. You guys obviously need to do some research. No Spoonfeeding, You need to download a source that has it, and learn from it. That’s how you learn to “Code.” Can’t be spoonfed your whole life.[/quote]
Sowwy… and also, true it is a 317, I just didn’t wanna say anything about it cus :superman: over there got it nice and done
